Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other like they’re daring me to ignore them any longer. My wife’s voice echoes in my head—“We agreed to share the chores, remember?”—and guilt prickles at my skin. But my phone buzzes, and I’m snapped back to my other world. As a telemarketer, I’m supposed to be ready, script in hand, to answer every question about our new service. Lately, though, the calls have been brutal. Prospects keep asking about technical details the script barely covers, and my supervisor expects me to handle every objection smoothly, no matter how lost I feel.

I glance at the laundry, then at my headset. If I fold now, I’ll fall behind on my call quota. If I keep calling, the laundry will keep growing, and I’ll be letting my wife down. My chest tightens as I try to figure out which expectation to meet first, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in from either side.
